options.text: Writing about real events and facts

options.feedback: Poetry can be fiction or nonfiction.

3-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: What types of nonfiction articles are there?

options.text: News, science, history, biography, and how-to

3-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: How do authors make nonfiction engaging?

options.text: Using interesting details, examples, and clear explanations

3-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: What is a fact vs. an opinion?

options.text: A fact is true and can be proven; an opinion is a belief

3-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: Why should nonfiction articles cite sources?

options.text: To show where information comes from and prove accuracy

3-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: What is the main purpose of a news article?
How do good nonfiction writers avoid bias?

options.text: By presenting facts accurately and showing multiple perspectives

3-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: What is a headline in an article?

options.text: The main title that summarizes the story

3-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: How do you identify reliable sources for nonfiction?

options.text: Look for credible authors, citations, and reputable publishers

3-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: What does it mean to fact-check?

options.text: To verify that claims are true using reliable sources
A longer nonfiction story that explores a topic in depth

3-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: Why is organization important in nonfiction writing?

options.text: It helps readers understand information clearly and logically

3-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What is a chapter in a book?

options.text: A division of a book that contains part of the story

3-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: Why do authors use chapter breaks?

options.text: To give readers a place to pause and to organize the story

3-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What is character development?

options.text: How a character changes and grows throughout a story

options.feedback: It is central to good stories.

3-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What is the plot of a book?

options.text: The sequence of events that make up the story

3-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What is the climax of a story?

options.text: The most exciting point where the main conflict reaches its peak

3-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What is a subplot?

options.text: A secondary story that supports the main plot
The only story in a book

3-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What does foreshadowing mean?

options.text: A hint about future events in the story

3-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: How do you predict what will happen next in a book?

options.text: By looking for clues, patterns, and character motivation
Only by reading the end first

3-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What is the theme of a book?

options.text: The main message or idea the author wants to communicate

3-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What does it mean to sympathize with a character?

options.text: To understand and feel for a character's struggles

3-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What is a narrator?
Why do readers bond with characters?

options.text: Through shared experiences, emotions, and character growth
Readers do not bond with characters

options.text: To give readers a place to pause and to organize the story

7-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What is character development?

options.text: How a character changes and grows throughout a story

options.feedback: It is central to good stories.

7-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What is the plot of a book?

options.text: The sequence of events that make up the story

7-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What is the climax of a story?

options.text: The most exciting point where the main conflict reaches its peak

7-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What is a subplot?

options.text: A secondary story that supports the main plot
The only story in a book

7-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What does foreshadowing mean?

options.text: A hint about future events in the story

7-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: How do you predict what will happen next in a book?

options.text: By looking for clues, patterns, and character motivation
Only by reading the end first

7-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What is the theme of a book?

options.text: The main message or idea the author wants to communicate

7-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What does it mean to sympathize with a character?

options.text: To understand and feel for a character's struggles

7-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What is a narrator?
Why do readers bond with characters?

options.text: Through shared experiences, emotions, and character growth
Readers do not bond with characters

What is nonfiction?

options.text: Writing about real events and facts

options.feedback: Poetry can be fiction or nonfiction.

8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: What types of nonfiction articles are there?

options.text: News, science, history, biography, and how-to

8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: How do authors make nonfiction engaging?

options.text: Using interesting details, examples, and clear explanations

8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: What is a fact vs. an opinion?

options.text: A fact is true and can be proven; an opinion is a belief

8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: Why should nonfiction articles cite sources?

options.text: To show where information comes from and prove accuracy

8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: What is the main purpose of a news article?
How do good nonfiction writers avoid bias?

options.text: By presenting facts accurately and showing multiple perspectives

8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: What is a headline in an article?

options.text: The main title that summarizes the story

8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: How do you identify reliable sources for nonfiction?

options.text: Look for credible authors, citations, and reputable publishers

8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: What does it mean to fact-check?

options.text: To verify that claims are true using reliable sources

8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: What is a feature article?

options.text: A longer nonfiction story that explores a topic in depth

8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.prompt: Why is organization important in nonfiction writing?

options.text: It helps readers understand information clearly and logically

8-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.prompt: What is a chapter in a book?

options.text: A division of a book that contains part of the story

options.text: To give readers a place to pause and to organize the story

The only story in a book

options.text: A hint about future events in the story
